CONSTITUTION OF THE REPUBLIC OF SINGAPORE
(AMENDMENT NO. 3) BILL


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [4th October, 1990],

    "That the Bill be now read a Second time." - [First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence].

    Question again proposed.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, yesterday, in moving the Second Reading of the Bill, the First Deputy Prime Minister disclosed to the House that he had unanimity in the Cabinet in introducing this amendment Bill. To me, it clearly shows that his new style of political leadership and government indicates a clear confidence that it can convince the people of Singapore that it is a caring government but, more importantly, Sir, it shows the First Deputy Prime Minister's vision for Singapore beyond the nineties.

    His ability to convince his Cabinet to go along with this idea of Elected President came through after much thought and rumination, although the idea was attributed to the Prime Minister but the details were worked out by his team. This augurs well, Sir, for the future of Singapore when he takes over as the next Prime Minister of Singapore sometime next month.

    Sir, I have been in this House since 1963 and out of seven general elections, I fought six of them. So I know what it is like

Column: 510

to go to the people time and again at each general election to secure their mandate. I can tell you, Sir, that even you will not disagree with me that that was not easy.

    But we must all look ahead. Not many human beings can live 100 years or so. A human being must die. He must go away, and the power he holds cannot last very long. One day, someone will step into his shoes. So when I see this new generation of leaders, confident of their ability to govern Singapore and to make it a better Singapore in the nineties and beyond, I feel reassured. They know that one day they too will have to go.

    When they introduced the idea of the Elected President, I participated in the debate on the motion moved by the Member for Kebun Baru on 11th August 1988. I put in my contribution in the debate and I would not want to bore the House with what I had said. What I said on 11th August 1988 are still relevant today.

    The evolution of a political system is not one that is easy to come by. It is ever changing and evolving. When I was leading a parliamentary delegation to Japan in 1987, the Japanese parliamentarians told me that it took them 80 years to evolve their kind of parliamentary system - the DIET and the House of Concillors. But we introduced our system based on the British Westminster parliamentary system. We adopted it, changed it, and sometimes we made Constitutional

Column: 511

amendments. It may interest the House that at one time the two-thirds majority required for the Second and Third Readings of the Amendment Bill to the Constitution was simply put aside to allow for a voting by a simple majority. I was one of those who said, "Look. It is an important piece of legislation on which the political system and government will have to work. Therefore, we have to take it very seriously." Therefore, any amendment to the Constitution must require a two-thirds majority. In other words, the two-thirds majority for any amendment to be made to the Constitution has been adhered to.

    Sir, I can understand the younger generation leaders' concern when they come to the question of sharing political power. I am very happy to note that they are confident that they can build upon what the old guards had built in the last 31 years. We have a credit balance of not less than $30 billion, as disclosed by the First Deputy Prime Minister in this House yesterday. This amount does not take into account all the infrastructural facilities, such as the 6,000-7,000 blocks of HDB flats, the airport, port, PUB and Telecom. Surely, Sir, these will add up to a bigger sum and we must realise that about 87% of our people are housed in HDB flats. This is indeed an achievement which I think very few countries in the world have attained. But for the younger generation leaders to come and say that they want an Elected President and to vest in him certain veto powers, that kind of power sharing is not easy to come by. It is political maturity being manifested.

    Sir, I was reminded of a comment by Lord Acton who lived in the 19th century, 1834. He was a British liberal historian and moralist and was known to be the first great modern philosopher of resistance to the evil state, whether its form be authoritarian, democratic, or socialist. And he made a comment that, "Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely." He said this in a letter.

    Members of the House can see that the Government has a lot of power and yet it is prepared to vest it in another person -the Elected President plus his Council of Pre-

Column: 512

sidential Advisors - powers in certain areas. This power-sharing is indeed a very welcome move and it shows once again that the second generation of leaders has got the guts and gumption to say, "Yes, under the present system, we can do better but with an amended system where certain powers are to be vested in the Elected President, we can do even better."

    Think again of the billions of dollars that we have accumulated. That was not easy to come by. On average, it is about $1 billion per year since 1959. But to "fritter it away" - to use the term mentioned by the First Deputy Prime Minister - through bad government is easy. If there is extravagance, wastefulness, unnecessary expenditure, then what happens? The country goes down. If the country goes down, I do not think there is any hope for Singapore. Therefore, the Elected President's job is to make sure that it does not happen.

    Sir, yesterday, I heard several of my colleagues in the Backbench spoke. I am happy to note their contributions. Some voiced their concerns, some made comments, but all these would definitely be taken into consideration by the Select Committee which will be set up after the Second Reading of this Bill. However, Sir, I was not present in the House to hear the speech from the Non-Constituency Member, Dr Lee, except gleaning through the newspapers today. I can understand his comments because he has been long in politics. But I think I would not be too unkind to him nor too critical of him when I say this because I happen to be around for so long. He was also in the PAP government of 1959 when he served as Parliamentary Secretary until he and his group broke away in 1961 to form the Barisan Sosialis. Perhaps he can now tell the House and throw some light on what happened in those years, especially when I look around, most of the Members of this House are quite young. I would not say they are "new". He could tell us why he and his group left the PAP to form the Barisan Sosialis and to contest in the 1963 general elections with some 44 candidates, if my memory serves me right, and wanted to capture political power through the ballot, the one-man-one-vote system, and they were very confident of winning the elections.

Column: 513



    What would have happened if they had won? Yesterday, in the Members' Room, after I had a cup of tea with Dr Lee I asked him this. But if he could spare some time, he could tell us what happened. Sometime in 1965/1966, when he was Chairman of the Barisan Sosialis, he told his Barisan Sosialis MPs to resign from Parliament and to take to extra-parliamentary struggle. As a result, the Barisan Sosialis boycotted the 1968 general elections. Acts of vandalism were committed. But strange enough, after some years, the Barisan Sosialis decided to come back and participate in the general elections. That was something interesting, but they did not win any seat at all until the 1988 general elections when Dr Lee himself went over to the Workers' Party. Now, he is an NCMP and making contributions in this House.

    I treat him with a great deal of respect because he stands firm on his convictions. But that is altogether a different matter when we come to look at Singapore as a whole. How we want to chart the course of our destiny? Are we for the future of Singapore? Are we for the people of Singapore? Are they going to have a better life? Better opportunities? That is what counts.

    He mentioned that the Elected President works against the Opposition. If I were to take a different scenario, the Elected President is in position to ensure the continued survival of Singapore. He has veto powers and he is there to make sure that Singapore continues. But then there comes a group of people who says, "Change." Then what happens? There is no guarantee. A fresh election may result. All the billions of dollars can be frittered away in no time through electioneering promises. The value of properties would just simply plummet because of a weak, inept Government wanting to play to the gallery and please the people with soft options in their policies.

    But, Sir, at the end of this debate on the Second Reading and the Bill committed to a Select Committee, I sincerely hope that all those who have the interest of Singapore at heart should come forward and make their contributions, be they critical or ways and means on how better we can

Column: 514

improve upon this Bill. At the same time, I say that there is no damage done, political damage or otherwise, if we go through the Second Reading and make it a reality when it comes to the Third Reading. In place, we have the Elected President that would help, in my view, make Singapore a much, much better place for all Singaporeans.

    On that note, Sir, I would like to compliment the First Deputy Prime Minister and his team for the confidence in being able to carry out this paramount duty to ensure that Singapore lasts as long as time.

    Sir, I support the Bill.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Bill. The arguments in support of an Elected President were quite exhaustively stated by the First Deputy Prime Minister yesterday in the Second Reading on this Bill. They are also set out quite clearly in the White Paper and I do not intend to repeat these arguments. I would really like to just underline one main point made by the First Deputy Prime Minister yesterday, and that is, our present system lacks checks and balances.

    We have, of course, operated this system for the last 25 years and this system is one where power is very highly concentrated, I would say even entirely reposed, in one institution. There is not the same diffusion of power or the sharing of power that we have in many other nations with a parliamentary democracy system, such features as two Houses of Parliament, Councils of Rulers, State Governments, Local Councils and so on. In these countries, power is in fact shared among many institutions. In fact, offhand, I cannot think of any other nation that has power as highly concentrated in one institution as we have here in Singapore. And the power is in fact concentrated in the Cabinet. We have, of course, Parliament, but in a system with strong party discipline, it is in fact the top leadership, ie, the Cabinet, that exercises real power. Even in the United Kingdom with its very long parliamentary tradition, there is a strong view emerging that the ability of party leaders to appeal directly to the public through the mass

Column: 515

media, coupled with strong party discipline, has in fact resulted in a very significant and marked shift of power from Parliament to the Government leaders, ie, the Cabinet. If this is so in UK, with its very long tradition in operating the system, it should not be surprising that it is so in Singapore and that power is so very concentrated in one group. We have a much shorter experience of parliamentary democracy and with few, if any, non-Government institutions which have any significant influence on our society and nation.

    The First Deputy Prime Minster pointed out that the system has worked and worked very well, not because of the quality of the institution but because of the quality of the people and quality of the leadership. We cannot assume that our past experience will be in fact projected into the future, that what has happened in the past will continue to be the case in the future. I think it will be tempting fortune beyond prudence to continue a system that depends so overwhelmingly on having persons of integrity and competence in political leadership. There must be a combination of good people and sound institutions. I think I need not elaborate on this. Members must be aware of many countries which have very fine constitutions but have, nevertheless, come to grief. So we must have a balance of both good constitutional provisions, good institutions and good leaders.

    The institution of an Elected President with only veto powers is one way of introducing some check on the power of the Government. When we in Cabinet considered this subject and we have in fact thought about it for a very long time, we were very conscious of the problems and dangers of giving too much power to one man. We were conscious that we should not tilt the balance and make the Elected President an executive President. The Bill has been very carefully crafted so that the elected Government is not fettered unduly. It is not a sharing of power in the normal administration of the nation's affairs. The elected Government can conduct its business without interference from the

Column: 516

President. It is only a sharing of power in certain special and exceptional circumstances and these are laid out in the Bill as well as in the White Paper.

    Since we became independent, we have changed our Constitution a number of times in order to meet our own peculiar circumstances and needs. This particular Bill that is before the House today is one way of shaping what we have inherited to meet our needs as we see them today and as we see them developing over the next few decades.

     Mr Chay Wai Chuen (Brickworks GRC): Thank you, Mr Speaker, for giving me this opportunity to speak.

    I wish to speak in support of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment No. 3) Bill. This amendment is a constitutional landmark for Singapore. After more than 30 years of executive rule under a Prime Minister, the question is often posed: why do we need an Elected President? It is not that our institution of Government has failed us in its period of history. On the contrary, this institution has grown and its modus operandi has worked to the visible progress of Singapore. However, there is one institution in my mind whose modus operandi has hinged very crucially on the outcome of a collective decision in which the extraneous and the extrinsic can play havoc with any consideration of rational decision-making in constitutional government. What do I mean?

    The Westminster style first-past-the-post system of our parliamentary democracy is uniquely devised for a strong parliamentary government. A governing party can win a big majority of seats in Parliament and yet obtain only a small majority of votes. For example, in the 1963 elections, only 47% of the total votes went to the PAP and yet it won 37 out of 51 seats, ie, 72% of the seats. The example of Britain under Margaret Thatcher in the last few elections is also a good pointer. While the Opposition always decry against this, yet in another time when they are more ready, it can also work to their advantage. The knife can cut both ways.

Column: 517



    What is wrong with the opposition having majorities in elections and forming the government? Obviously, in our parliamentary system of government, there is nothing wrong. What is wrong when the PAP loses its predominance but maintains its majority in government and the Opposition gains ground? The hon. Member for Punggol has given you some background to what could have happened in 1963. The danger in this scenario is that factionalism will develop in the PAP and in the Opposition. Various interest groups and pressure groups, skilled by the experience of participatory democracy and finding new levers in the political balance, will exert influence on parliamentary government, and parliamentary politics will find new directions in compromise and the lobby. The interest of the nation may very well degenerate into an aggregation of interests of the various interest groups and pressure groups, and the Opposition will swing the balance to affect the decision of government. This is not a far-fetched scenario. It is not a scenario of political decay.

    There are many examples in present-day democracies with this compromise and lobby system of representative government. The best example is the United States. For a big country like the US, through a federal framework of government, the country needs this bargaining system simply because the country is too big for power to be concentrated at the epicentre in Washington. America and her people can walk many ways and arrive at their destiny.

    But for a small country like Singapore, such a case will lead to compromised politics for the city state, lacking in clear direction and purpose. With only a small margin of error between success and failure, it is important to ensure that the correct long-term policies for stability and prosperity for the city state are adopted at the right time. Hence, it is important that we explore new institutions to ensure continuity and stability that can add longer term perspective to our choice and determination of policies. Such an institution is the proposed Elected Presidency.

    First, it is important to remember that the proposed Elected President does not initiate policies. To that extent, the Execu-

Column: 518

tive arm of the present parliamentary representative government is not affected. He can only put a stop sign in certain safeguarded areas if he does not concur with the policy decisions put forward by the Government and by Parliament. Thus, it is important for the public to bear in mind that he does not usurp the power of the Prime Minister and Parliament. The Elected Presidency enables us to tackle directly and openly a second order problem in our parliamentary system of government -one that we have all along conveniently swept under the carpet in our discussion of parliamentary democracy - the problem of maintaining the integrity of government and government institutions.

    Because the PAP under Mr Lee Kuan Yew has been able to maintain the integrity of government institutions does not mean that under changed circumstances, such will always be the case. In fact, parliamentary representative government is basically confrontational and dissentious. Because of the need for representation, the views and interests expressed are often parochial and short term. A very good example recently was when we hear of rice farmers in Japan demonstrating in Tokyo for greater protection with powerful parliamentary lobbyists behind them. One wonders why the Japanese pay so dearly for their rice.

    Voting by Members of Parliament of the party in power and the Opposition is governed by the Whip in true Westminster style. But for stability, the integrity of government and government institutions must prevail even in the midst of a parliamentary tussle. That we do not have much of a tussle these days does not mean there will be no parliamentary tussle in the future. The Member for Potong Pasir would surely agree. Such integrity can better be guaranteed with the institution of the Elected Presidency who does not have to partake of the parliamentary fray. The Elected Presidency is a new milestone in our political development. For the past 30 years, Singapore has achieved much in the way of economic development. We must also match our economic development with the necessary institutions in political structures to support our long-term overall development.

Column: 519



    I believe we should evaluate this proposed institution under the following criteria:

    Firstly, does the Elected Presidency add to the system of checks and balances in our representative democracy? The Elected President can only withhold his assent. He does not initiate policy which rests with the Prime Minister and his Cabinet. It provides power to the President to withhold assent for the drawdown of the reserves of the statutory boards and the government-owned companies, not accumulated by the current government. It provides protection for the trust money held by the Central Provident Fund. These are very strong institutions held closely by our people. The Elected Presidency will be able to safeguard the integrity.

    Secondly, does the Elected Presidency take away from the safeguard of civil liberties of Singaporeans under the existing constraints? Nowhere in the proposed legislation does it take away these civil liberties from the people. In fact, it provides additional safeguards that the integrity of the CPIB and the Presidential Council for Religious Harmony should protect the civil liberties of Singaporeans because the Elected President can disagree and withhold his assent.

    Thirdly, does it provide a stabiliser to any factious parliament and any unstable parliamentary government that may arise? As I have explained earlier, I think it does.

    Finally, does the Elected Presidency take away the excessive burden of responsibility on the Prime Minister which our system has been operating up to now? The answer is yes. Such an innovation may not be a disadvantage. It represents a more politically mature society that we are now, with power sharing to a new institution to safeguard the integrity of State.

    I believe this is good for three reasons:-

    Firstly, it provides potentially more room for a more balanced approach by the Prime Minister, especially when he is committed to building consensus in a partici-

Column: 520

patory democracy. He is also, by the presence of the Elected Presidency, forced more to consider the potential bottleneck because of the need for assent and thereby to persuade and to find more middle ground among various sections of the populace.

    Secondly, the people will be assured that the Government by meritocracy will always prevail because of the second level check on the integrity of the civil service and the statutory boards.

    Thirdly, I believe this additional institution will lend stability and assurance which will enable and ensure that Singapore will continue to attract foreign investment and that Singaporeans will find it worthwhile to save and invest. Because of the safeguards in the Elected Presidency, Parliament and the Government cannot easily run a deficit or draw down the accumulated reserves. This virtually guarantees the long-term external value of the Singapore dollar. By this control measure, foreigners will always have faith in the long-term stability of our Singapore dollar, and the worth of assets owned by Singaporeans will not fall due to a depreciating currency.

    Finally, Sir, the proposed Elected President does not exercise his decision and his prerogative in splendid isolation. It is important to repeat that the Elected President is elected by the people. His constituency is Singapore.

    There is also a provision for a Council of Presidential Advisors whose members include ordinary citizens nominated by the Chairman of the Public Service Commission from the civil service and by the Prime Minister. This body which advises the Elected President is another institution which allows for the non-partisan scrutiny of Supply Bills and issues pertaining to the responsibility of the Elected President. These Advisors are in touch with the mainstream of development of Singapore and will be able to advise the Elected President accordingly.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Amendment Bill.

     Mr Charles Chong (Sembawang GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Bill moved by the First Deputy Prime Minister.

Column: 521



    Many of the points in support of the Bill have already been addressed and elaborated upon by the many speakers before me. I shall try not to repeat them but to comment on a few of the issues raised.

    First of all, I would like to commend the Government on its far-sightedness in introducing a Bill that would ensure better government, even though such a Bill may effectively dilute its powers at a time when the Government controls nearly all the seats in Parliament and there is no urgent need to give up any of its powers.

    I remember during the previous general election campaign, calls were made by the Opposition parties for more checks and balances on the PAP Government. This Bill, if passed, will provide significant checks on the Government's actions on issues pertaining to the ISA, CPIB investigations, religious harmony, key appointments in the civil service as well as to provide an additional safeguard on our reserves. I was therefore a bit surprised to hear the NCMP express his party's strong opposition to the Bill. Sir, I suspect the main objection to the Elected President proposal is because the current Prime Minister appears to be an ideal candidate. The prospect of having another PAP man elected by the population as the President probably makes them feel a little bit less enthusiastic about the Bill, despite the desire to have more checks and balances on the Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as the President has to be elected by the people of Singapore, whatever the outcome of the election, the choice of the electorate would eventually prevail. However, a situation may arise where there may be only one candidate standing for President. The electorate may not have much of a choice in this instance if the sole candidate is returned unopposed. In order that there can be no doubt that the choice of the people will prevail, I would like to suggest that in cases where there is only one candidate, the electorate should be given a choice of either rejecting or endorsing the candidate. If more than 50% of the eligible voters were to reject the candidate, then fresh nominations should be called.

Column: 522



    Sir, I support the stringent conditions that Presidential candidates must satisfy before qualifying as candidates. The responsibilities of the President require specialist knowledge and experience. Consequently, it would be prudent to limit the candidates to only those who have proven track records. I agree with the views expressed yesterday that no matter how stringent and careful the selection process might be, the less competent can still occasionally sneak through. However, if there are no stringent criteria in existence, then the possibility of the less competent sneaking through would invariably be very much higher.

    Sir, I do not think that we need to feel apologetic if the conditions for qualifying appear to be difficult to achieve. Singaporeans deserve the right to choose from the best a Head of State that would be most competent to safeguard our assets and to provide a check on the elected government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I find it difficult to go along with the view expressed yesterday in this House that the Bill, if passed, could be used as a second chance for the electorate to change their minds about the government they have put into power. I would like to think that the role of the Elected President is to act as a safeguard against bad decisions by the Government and not as a means by a fickle electorate to prematurely throw out the Government.

    Finally, Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to comment on the proposed Article 22J of the Bill which appears to imply that the President, while in office, is above the law and is immune from prosecution for any action done by him either in his official or private capacity. Sir, I am aware that there are provisions in the existing Constitution that give the President immunity from prosecution and I can go along with the rationale for providing the President with immunity for his actions in his official capacity. However, I am unable to see the requirement to extend this immunity to cover all his actions accomplished in his private capacity as well.

    With that, Mr Speaker, Sir, I am glad to note that the Bill will be referred to a Select Committee where more views and comments can be heard and discussed.

Column: 523



     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe( In Malay): Mr Speaker, the commitment of this Bill to a Select Committee will enable the members of the public to have an opportunity to come forward and offer their views and feedback. As we know, the Bill will introduce a fundamental change in the Constitution of Singapore. The people must take this good opportunity to discuss this Bill thoroughly and to contribute their views and suggestions, in the interests of Singapore and our future generations.

moves to privatise PUB and Telecom? Why the need to retain them on the list? When a new government takes over, whatever it inherits from the previous government cannot be touched unless the Elected President agrees. But if he does not, then the government has to raise its own money. However, there will be arguments over whether some of the profits or savings generated from on-going projects, projects which were started by the previous government, belong to the new government, or cannot be touched still.

block the spending of reserves for such purposes.

In essence, there is no difference between our proposal and the suggestion that there should be an Upper House to supervise or to comment on Bills debated in this House.

    We think this scheme is more workable because when you have a Senate, and let us assume it is an elected Senate, first, you have the problem of finding a sufficient number of people to stand for elections to the Senate. You need about 20 to 30 people to make it effective. And secondly, how do we ensure that people who are elected into the Senate have the qualities which we are looking for? There is no control. It is an Upper House which in a sense duplicates the functions of the Lower House. In other words, we should be looking for 20 to 30 senators who are politically superior to Members of this House. Can you find them? If you can, and you are satisfied that these are people who can look after our interests much better than MPs over here, perhaps you can give it a try. But I suggest that for the time being, let us concentrate on a small Upper House, a small Senate with six appointed Council members to advise one elected Senator or the President. We have control over the quality of men or women who will be on the Council and there are certain safeguards to ensure that the person who stands for election as Elected President has the desired attributes.

12. I think we can consider that. But whatever numbers that we have, we settle for equal weightage, that means, the President will nominate a certain number, the Prime Minister will nominate an equal number, and the Chairman, PSC an equal number. Chairman of statutory boards and Boards of Directors of big companies, are no more than a proxy for the attributes that we are looking for.

    Now, let us deal with the emotional issue, too much power in the hand of one person. To me, I think this is just nothing but an emotional reaction, a gut reaction that we are creating a position and investing too much power in one man. Let us examine this logically and objectively. Are we, in fact, giving absolute power to one man so that he will be corrupted absolutely, to address the fear of Dr Lee Siew-Choh? What powers are we giving to the Elected President? He has the power to veto a Supply Bill when that Supply Bill dips into past reserves. But there is an override mechanism to that. Unless members of the Council agree with him, his veto will have to be referred back to this House. In other words, he is not alone in exercising that veto power. And if he goes against the advice of the Council, the House can override him by a two-thirds majority.

    On key appointments, what powers are we giving him? He does not appoint any member to the Public Service Commission or to the statutory boards. He merely has the power to withdraw consent, if he does not agree with the nomination of the Prime Minister or the Government. To weigh his power against the power of the Prime Minister, who has more power? I think it is clear that the Prime Minister has much more power than the President. The President's powers are limited to certain well-defined areas and even then there is a system of check on his exercise of power. We should not be taken in by glib remarks that we are giving too much power to one person. I think that is only an emotional reaction. It is not based on logic or facts. A more valid concern is when the President disagrees with the Prime Minister and there is an impasse, or sometimes, a constitutional crisis. I think that is a more valid concern because it is possible that the President will, from time to time, disagree with the elected Government and then you have an impasse. What do you do under such circumstances? We have also addressed that and I believe the way we have crafted this proposal allows for the Government to carry on without the whole country being paralysed.

Are civil servants not paid because there are no funds available? The proposal is, if the new budget is not approved by the President, the Government can fall back on the old budget which has been approved. So funds are available, governing can carry on whilst the Government submits a fresh budget for approval by the President.

One was Mr John Tower was a defence consultant and, as defence consultant, he dealt with defence industry contractors and, therefore, there was a conflict of interest in his becoming Secretary of Defence. How was that resolved? It was resolved by the President nominating somebody else and that somebody else is Mr Cheney, the present Secretary of Defence. Likewise, in Singapore, should the Prime Minister's nomination be rejected for the first time by the President, then he has to submit a new name for the second time. If he is again rejected, then he will do so for the third time, which was what President Reagan did in respect of judges.
